Hi,

I am creating a tool called the Automated Feature Tracer (AFT) which 
will generate an execution trace of an entire test suite, storing 
the results so that they can be viewed in JQuery (a query-based code 
browser for Eclipse).  The tool can tell you which code gets called 
by the test suite (and which doesn't).  It can also tell you which 
test calls each piece of code and a little bit about the stack at 
that point.  This would help you determine code coverage.

The AFT tool is not available for download yet (I'm planning on 
finihsing my thesis first), but I would be happy to make it 
available and help you use it if you wanted to use the tool on your 
system.  


good luck,
--andrew


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Chad Woolley <lists@t...> wrote:
> Vladimir Ritz Bossicard wrote:
> > 
> >>> murukeshcts wrote:
> >>> 
> >>
> >>>> > hai all,
> >>>> >   Is there any tool available..that i can integrated with 
WSAD so that
> >>>> > i can check for the code coverage of the JUnitcode which  a 
person
> >>>> > writes in his project.
> >>
> >>> 
> >>> I don't know about WSAD integration, but there are several 
test coverage 
> >>> tools out there, including Clover and Jester. They are easily 
integrated 
> >>> with Ant.
> > 
> > 
> > jcoverage <http://www.jcoverage.com> works nicely too
> 
> Hansel is also good, and it works in Eclipse, so should also work 
fine in WSAD. 
>   Hansel is nice within the IDE because it gives you immediate 
feedback when 
> running the test, and you can click on the error line in the 
integrated JUnit 
> runner and go directly to the uncovered code.
> 
> -- Chad
